bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Arnold Hutschnecker, was born in Austria in 1898 and served during World War I before studying psychiatry at Humboldt University of Berlin. Practicing first in Berlin, his opposition to the Nazi governement let him to emigrate to to New York in 1938.

Hutschnecker gained notoriety for his 1951 book The Will to Live which became a bestseller and attracted Senator Richard M. Nixon as a client in 1952. Hutschnecker remained Nixon's personal therapist, friend, and consultant through his years as President. Hutschnecker later became known for his public stances on the psychology of political leaders and criminals as children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, including copies of letter to and from Richard M. Nixon; publications by Hutschnecker; newspaper clippings; diaries; photographs; Richard Nixon materials, including a copy of Hutschnecker's unpublished typescript, "Richard Nixon: His Rise to Power His Self Defeat."

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is unprocessed and is likely disorganized. Individual items may be difficult to find.
